query: Pisgah Monster Cross gravel race Brevard

videos.title: This race was a beast! | Pisgah Monster Cross 2025
videos.description:
2025 Monster Cross on the awesome gravel roads and trails of Brevard, North Carolina. Highly recommend visiting and doing this event, camping is just across the street and the MTBing and roads are amazing!

Thank you to the Black Bibs for supporting this off road season
get some:
https://theblackbibs.com/products/the-black-shorts-ultimate?utm_source=williamrhardin

Donate to the Hurricane Recovery Effort:
https://www.nccommunityfoundation.org/nonprofits/disaster-relief-fund/hurricane-helene-response

Contact me: 
hardinwilliam122@gmail.com

Instagram:
https://www.instagram.com/williamrhardin
videos.transcript:
Welcome to Pisga Monster Cross. This is
a race in the mountains of North
Carolina. And
we start off under this little gate.
Sierra and I on the left there I just
passed are doing a few gravel races this
year as part of our little off-road

quite high here trying to get to the
front. I know it starts off see um a
over there to the right cross superstar.
Um
get over here past Alex and Eric. But
we're doing a little off-road offseason
situation presented by the Black Bibs
and Team Winston Salem. So, we're
rocking these
salmon, I believe is the official term,
colored jerseys from the Black Bibs and
also some black bibs from the Black
Bibs. And
we're doing a few off-road races. So,
starting off here in Pisa Monstercross.
I actually forgot to get the
map routed before the start here. So,
had to figure that out while we were on
the move. And I guess there's a few
hundred people in this race, which was
pretty huge, but a lot of these gravel
roads were pretty chunky. And I had 40
mm tires on, which is going to be a
theme later on. On the road sections, it
was great. But when we started off,
there was Cypress Cory and Carson
Beckett. They're with uh full-blown
mountain bikes, 120 travel mountain
bikes with mountain bike tires. And that
was kind of worrying because they've
done these roads and trails many times.
And so I would imagine they were
adequately prepared starting off up this
little road. It's like a 10 minute, 15
minute climb. and guys were going pretty
hard, but I was kind of trying to get to
the front so I wouldn't get lost on the
descent as far as getting out descended
by guys on mountain bikes. So,
getting as far forward as I possibly
can. And
see on the right there, I think his
name's Jack with Felosia Sport. Caught
up to Thomas Turner there on the left.
And yeah, it's kind of like a double
track, like a an off-road
a uh a jeep trail. I guess a double
track is the best, like a ATV trail. And
you have to take some choice lines just
cuz there's some ruting out happening
and some deeper gravel over in those
tracks there. But trying to move up the
best I could behind. Got some Lars
there. Everybody's got big tires on
their mountain bikes these days. I had
talked to Sierra and before the
hurricane, these roads were a little
less torn up, but now they are actually
pretty rugged roads. So, hurricane did a
lot of damage up here in the mountains
of North Carolina. If you can, I'll put
a little link to somewhere you can
donate uh to the hurricane effort. Back
to the race. I'm attacking
and
I'm not sure if this is a great idea or
not because it's so early in the race.
over four miles into a 74 mile race up
this hill. I kind of knew what was
coming. And there's a few more uphills,
but I also knew that on my 40 mil tires
compared to guys on mountain bike tires,
it wasn't going to be great for me. So,
I wanted to get as much space as
possible on these downhills just cuz
they were going to catch me. And I had
good better rolling resistance on a lot
of spots, especially the road spots. So,
I'm trying to get away from everybody I
possibly can. And I am sending this
descent quite hard. So,
taking some risks that maybe weren't
super necessary for miles into a 70ish
mile race, but
I felt like they were kind of necessary.
It's pretty chunky road and I kind of
wanted to see stuff before I hit it. I
have a big gear on this bike. Eventually
got caught and passed by those mountain
bikers and I dropped my chain.
the big gear, big 50 to ring usually
keeps stuff on, but uh this time it was
bouncing around. I'm not sure if my
clutch derailer is starting to wear out
and uh it's bouncing off the chain was
bouncing off the chain ring too much.
But it finishes up the single track
here. You can see Stephen there putting
a foot out, having to stop when the guy
in front of him, I think that's Bob. Oh
no, it is not. Might be Zeb. The guy in
I think Bob bobbled or maybe Zeb did.
and slowed up Stephen and he had to put
a foot out. But now I'm catching back up
to these two guys. And both Carson and
Cyprus are off the front at this point.
They had a much faster descent than
anybody else. I dropped my chain so I
they were gone. Uh but I had that attack
and it really split up the field. So
once that happened and everybody was
split up, kind of going into this
descent portion, I
was off the backish, had to catch up to
these guys before that single track. And
now we are descending quite fast. Bob up
there is
shooting this descent pretty hard. I get
past Seb trying to keep up with Bob, but
he's got mountain bike tires on his
gravel bike and I'm going to do the best
I can to keep up with him, but he's just
going around these corners like he's got
more traction than me, which with tires
that are probably 20 mil bigger than
mine, he's got more traction than me.
You're going to see me come around a few
of these corners and just lose the front
there, which was quite worrying many
times. And there's also a bunch of these
little mud sections that on a cross bike
I'm usually comfortable with, but um
some reason with this gravel bike going
30 miles an hour was not super
comfortable. We ended up catching
>> those two guys at the bottom. I think
Oakley was in front of Bob also and uh
caught back up to them and then
eventually I got back on the front
because this road section is perfect for
my gear with a 40mm tire. I got back on
the front and pushed the pace. caught
back up to Carson and Cypress here 13
miles in. Eventually, it was a bunch of
us together. So, we've got Oakley there
right in front of me. He's on fresh
allied bike. And I figured it was time
to go. There's a big road climb coming
up. So, I just attacked them after a
while. I turned my GoPro on and knew I
had to wait after that little beep
before attacking. So, I gave it some
time and then sent an attack once the
road started to kick up a little more.
Nobody really responded, but I just kind
of maintained a gap. So, I was doing
like probably 360 watts on most uphills.
Eventually, Steven tried to catch back
up on that. Um, but there was a few
gravel sections he just couldn't keep up
with. Eventually, I'm off the front for
a while. And there's this descent here
called Medusa.
It had
a wild section. You could probably hear
me say, "What is this?" And on these 40
mil tires, I was underbiked. Absolutely
underbiked. And the guys just on the
mountain bikes just catch kept catching
up to me to the point where I would get
like a two-minute gap, I think, and then
they would just blow through all of it
once we got to these more technical
gravel descents. And even the less
technical gravel descents, I think they
were descending way quicker than I was
on those big bikes. So, it was
definitely a uh no one had the right
bike kind of scenario. On the road
sections, which there were a decent
amount, I definitely had a good bike for
it. And then everywhere else the
mountain bike seemed to be much quicker.
So maybe a drop bar mountain bike would
have been ideal or like a gravel bike
with mountain bike tires. I did this
descent as fast as I could though. And
you can see I was catching up to I think
Alex on the moto there. We were having a
blast at the end of that little Medusa
descent. He had like a little bobble and
looked back at me and said, "Man, that
was crazy." Like, "Yeah, that is crazy."
Anyway, we're going down this hill super
hard. I've got many miles left to go,
but I just kept 360 on the uphills and
then tried to just keep the pace on on
the downhills. Eventually on one of the
last uphills, you can see we've got it's
a 66 mile race. Five miles to go, I get
caught by Oakley. He comes out of
nowhere. Bridges like a twominute gap
and he's got this nice allied with the
like Ki, it's not the Dub Race Kings, I
think is what they used to be called.
Big old tires on there. I'm trying to
keep up with him. But you can see I'm
doing like a good bit of power for the
end of this race. I think I averaged
like 300 watts for four and a half, five
hours. It was a lot of watts. And for
him to be catching up to me was pretty
impressive. But he just like floats away
from me. I'm not sure if the if it's the
tires or he was just going that much
faster. I started catching back up to
him on the downhill. Um really risking
it here, like sliding around all the
corners. Uh but just was not making a
huge dent. Eventually I did catch real
close up to him and then I just had like
some incidents which we're going to see.
But I was racing down this downhill just
as fast as I could go. Like letting it
slide a little. Yeah, you can see it.
There is real chunky downhill. I was
willing to risk getting a flat just roll
it in the best I can. You can see, man,
this is like super chunky. These roads
are awesome. And this whole race was
organized super well.
right here. I actually lost the bars.
Um, and that was very scary. I caught
myself with my elbow, which yeah, that
was super frightening. And I was like,
man, I'm I'm going to need to take a
step back here in a second. But I kept
going as hard as I could down here. And
I was catching up to him. I had him in
sight. I figured, man, if we get to that
end, I know there are barriers at the
end. But right here, I went for another
pedal stroke and dropped my chain for
the second time. So, just immediately
tried to get it back on. Come to a stop,
get that chain back on. I don't think I
lost a ton of time getting that chain
back on, but I knew at this point with
two miles to go all downhill, that much
time lost was going to be nearly
impossible to recoup. So, I just pushed
in as hard as I could um to the finish
just in case he also had a similar
incident, but continued down through
that gravel descent and through the
pavement to get second place behind
Oakley. Finished up with bunch of blood
on my arm. Pretty gnarly. But this race
was excellently organized. Um the guys
did a great job. There were crossing
guards at everything. Aid stations were
great. barriers at the finish. Very cool
monster cross race through the mountains
of North Carolina. Thanks for watching.
See you.
[Music]

videos.title: I won a Gravel race called Monster Cross in Brevard, North Carolina
videos.description:
I will find any excuse to visit Brevard, North Carolina where I grew up going on camping trips with my family and eventually moved to for a couple years. This incredible gravel race, put on by Pisgah Productions, tests everything—climbs, technical descents, and pure grit. I’m excited to share my full race breakdown after taking the women’s win - on my redemption tour.

📍 Race: Monster Cross Challenge by Pisgah Productions https://www.pisgahproductions.com
📊 Strava Activity: https://www.strava.com/activities/15721440100
👩‍🏫 Coaching Inquiry: sierra@fascatcoaching.com
📸 Instagram: @Sierra_Mountains_

And hit like & subscribe if you want to idk

videos.title: Pisgah Monster Cross 2015 - Available in HD!
videos.description:
Pisgah Monster Cross 2015 (09/12/2015) – a tough event hosted by Pisgah Productions that begins and ends close to Brevard, North Carolina, in the depths of the Pisgah National Forest.

Depending on the year – odd vs even years – clockwise or anti-clockwise – the course features 8,000 feet or 11,000 feet of climbing – across 70 miles of paved and gravel road surfaces. Forty of those miles feature of some of the toughest gravel roads in the Pisgah National Forest, along with the highest paved road elevations of the Blue Ridge Parkway. For 2015, we were racing in the clockwise direction with 8,000 feet of climbing on tap.

Gravel Cyclist Race Report - http://wp.me/p4V4se-1Ia

Blog: GravelCyclist.com
Facebook.com/GravelCyclist
Vimeo.com/GravelCyclist
Instagram/GravelCyclist

videos.title: 2016 Pisgah Monster Cross: 70+ Miles, Climbing, Gravel and Beautiful Scenery. Available in 60FPS HD!
videos.description:
Saturday, September 10, 2016. JOM, K-Dogg, Mrs K-Dogg, Pfaff Daddy and Dr. Pain of the Gravel Cyclist drove a little ways to attend Pisgah Monster Cross in Brevard, North Carolina. 70+ miles, 9,000+ feet of climbing with gravel, climbing, descending, the Blue Ridge Parkway and amazing scenery.

JOM's race report: http://wp.me/p4V4se-3eV
K-Dogg's race report: http://wp.me/p4V4se-3gw

Pisgah Monster Cross website: http://pisgahproductions.com

Web: http://GravelCyclist.com
Facebook: http://facebook.com/GravelCyclist
Instagram - http://Instagram/GravelCyclist
Twitter - http://twitter.com/GravelCyclist
Vimeo - http://vimeo.com/GravelCyclist

videos.title: Gravel Cycling Greatness in Pisgah National Forest!
videos.description:
This video features gravel cycling on Anthony Creek Road and Edgemont Road, two fabulous gravel roads in Pisgah National Forest. Contact us to help plan your ultimate gravel cycling experience in and around Pisgah!

Many thanks to our friends of CycleHere Media for creating this awesome video!
